pdf_context: Graphical Abstract Freeze-then-Stress: Time-Resolved Building Resilience through the 21st Cen- tury with Scenario-Conditioned Weather Hongshan Guo Highlights Freeze-then-Stress: Time-Resolved Building Resilience through the 21st Cen- tury with Scenario-Conditioned Weather Hongshan Guo •Year-by-year sAMYs (2025–2095) preserve CORDEX daily signals •ERA5→NSRDB solar mapping yields realistic hourly GHI/DNI/DHI •Hot-tail exposure (>35◦C) rises by +1,600–5,100 h by the 2090s (city range). •Peak grows faster than energy; retail and hot-humid fail earliest •Scale: 852 year-by-year runs (3 types ×4 cities×71 years, 2025–2095) Freeze-then-Stress: Time-Resolved Building Resilience through the 21st Century with Scenario-Conditioned Weather Hongshan Guo Department of Architecture, The University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR, China Abstract Designing for climate resilience requires weather sequences that preserve both scenario- driven warming and realistic sub-daily variability. We generate scenario-conditioned Actual Meteorological Years (sAMYs) for 2025–2095 by locking CORDEX daily temperature (and solar) signals while restoring observed diurnal shape and multivariate covariance from ISD records; solar is harmonized via an ERA5 →NSRDB calibration. We then freeze present-day capacities and controls of three ASHRAE/DOE prototypes (Medium Office, Stand-alone Retail, Mid-rise Apartment) in four cities (Miami, Los Angeles, Toronto, Montreal) and stress them year-by-year. Validation shows the sAMYs match CORDEX daily warming and preserve event persistence while retaining realistic hourly structure. Results reveal that peak demand increases faster than annual energy, with the largest growth in hot- humid climates and in retail; offices in cool-humid climates show declining winter peaks and modest energy increases. Comfort exposure trends depend on the lens: setpoint-based unmet changes little, PMV highlights latent limitations (retail, Miami/LA), and adaptive captures expectation-driven exposure (apartments late-century). System diagnostics from EnergyPlus logs indicate a shift from controller-struggle to capacity-saturated operation in late decades, consistent with hours at coil/SAT caps. A severity–frequency map and a dry-bulb ×dew-point driver analysis attribute failures to sensible vs latent mechanisms, informing targeted adaptations (dehumidification, modest capacity bump, SAT reset/night purge). The sAMY corpus, code and metrics are released to support reproducible, time- resolved resilience assessments. Keywords: 1. Introduction Hot extremes and multi-day heatwaves are increasing in frequency, intensity, and per- sistence as the planet warms; even small increments in global mean temperature yield dis- cernible increases in hot-extreme occurrence and severity [1, 2]. For building resilience, the critical question is not performance under an average future slice, but whena design fails under plausible future sequences . We learn sub-daily structure from in-situ station observations via NOAA’s Integrated Surface Database (ISD) [3, 4]. Because the backbone network (ASOS/AWOS) is primarily at airports embedded in urban fabrics, these data offer city-proximal exposure compared with coarse reanalyses [5, 6]. Representativeness and siting follow the Local Climate Zones framework and canonical urban heat-island physics [7, 8]. Future daily-scale signals come from CORDEX, linked to CMIP and designed for im- pacts/adaptation [9, 10]. We adopt these day-by-day signals so that trends and event timing (e.g., hot-spell onset/persistence) are scenario-faithful.
